questions.text: A diabetic patient came to you and wished you namaste. While doing namaste you as a doctor observe his hand has this deformity?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question is unable to oppose the palmar surfaces of the hands and fingers(prayer sign). This is due to limited joint mobility syndrome or diabetic cheiroarthropathy or stiff hand syndrome.

It is not an arthropathy, but a process that involves the periarticular structures. It is a fibrosing syndrome resulting in thick waxy and tight skin on the dorsal aspect of MCP, PIP and DIP of fingers. Larger joints can also be involved.

It is seen in both type i and type ii diabetes and increases in frequency with age, disease duration and poor glycemic control.

NSAIDs and steroids are ineffective in management. Physical therapy and glycemic control are the treatment.

Hairy cell leukemia is a chronic and rare form of adult leukemia.Treatment options for HCL are -

Splenectomy results in prolonged remissions

Cladribine and deoxycoformycin are nucleosides associated with durable remissions, but associated with immunosuppression

Interferon α is used but not as effective as nucleosides

Chemotherapy refractory cases are treated with Vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor. More durable remission occurs once it is combined with rituximab.

questions.text: Most specific test of carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.solution:
The tests mentioned here are used at the bedside for diagnosing median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel.

Phalen's test is prolonged full flexion of digits reproducing the symptom of carpal tunnel.

Tinel's test is percussion over the carpal tunnel.

Durkan's test is otherwise called the carpal compression test, where direct compression over the carpal tunnel reproduces the symptoms.It is the most specific and sensitive test.

questions.text: Pacemaker is disposed in which bag
questions.solution:
The question deals with biomedical waste disposal. Pacemaker leads are made of metal alloys and hence should be disposed in blue cardboard box and not bags. So if blue box is given in the option that will be most appropriate. The closest option is blue bag.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

questions.text: What is not included in the MELD score?
questions.solution:
Meld score components: Serum bilirubin, inr and creatinine

Predictors of survival in liver transplant patients.

Serum sodium levels were added to it, since sodium is another important predictor of survival-MELD Na.

MELD score ranges between 6 and 40.

Prioritization of liver transplantation is based on MELD score

MELD determines the post transplantation mortality and waiting list mortality.

Score <15 is associated with a high post transplant mortality

questions.text: All of the following are measures used against COVID19 except?
questions.solution:
Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by the SARS CoV-2 virus. The virus can spread from an infected person’s mouth or nose in small liquid particles when they cough, sneeze, speak, sing or breathe. These particles range from larger respiratory droplets to smaller aerosols. It is important to practice respiratory etiquette, for example by coughing into a flexed elbow, and to stay home and self-isolate. Hand washing, sanitation and face masks are important to prevent Covid 19.

Disinfection using alcohol sanitizers containing at least 60% alcohol is recommended for prevention of COVID 19.

Biosafety levels (BSL) are used to identify the protective measures needed in a laboratory setting to protect workers, the environment, and the public. The levels are defined in Biosafety in Biomedical Laboratories (the BMBL). BSL-3 laboratories are used to study infectious agents or toxins that may be transmitted through the air and cause potentially lethal infections. Researchers perform all experiments in a biosafety cabinet. BSL-3 laboratories are designed to be easily decontaminated

Cultures of SARS-CoV-2 should be handled in a biosafety level 3 (BSL-3) laboratory using BSL practices

Inoculation of animals with infectious wild-type SARS CoV-2 should be conducted in an animal biosafety level 3 (ABSL-3) facility using absl-3 practices and respiratory protection.

Let us see the various biosafety levels

Reference: Https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/lab/lab-biosafety-guidelines.html

The ABCD2 score calculates the 3 month risk of stroke following a TIA.

Risk of stroke is 10-15% in the first 3 months of TIA

Most strokes occur within 2 days of TIA.

The time cut off in the score is 60 minutes and not 5 minutes.

Ordinal data is a categorical, statistical data type where the variables have natural, ordered categories and the distances between the categories are not known. Ordinal data is data which is placed into some kind of order or scale.

Nominal data is named data which can be separated into discrete categories which do not overlap. A common example of nominal data is gender; male and female

GCS and APACHE II scores are ordinal data.

questions.text: Gene Xpert tells resistance due to mutation in
questions.solution:
Xpert MTB/Rif otherwise known as GENE XPERT is a highly sensitive and specific real time nucleic acid amplification test for diagnosis of TB as well as rifampicin resistance with results available in <2 hours. Its sensitivity and specificity approaches that of liquid culture. Low bio safety and training requirements.

For diagnosis of TB: The specificity is 98% and sensitivity is 85%(overall), to be deleted with 98% sensitive for afb positives and 70% sensitive for afb negative patients.

For drug resistance detection: The sensitivity is 96% and specificity is 98%.

The resistance to rifampicin is associated with mutations in the RpoB gene in upto 95% cases. Hence the gene expert detects mutation in RpoB gene.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Inh resistance is due to mutations in KatG gene in 50-95% cases and INHA gene in 45% cases

Pyrazinamide mutations is due to PNCA gene mutation in 98% cases

Ethambutol resistance is due to mutations in EmbB gene in 50-65% cases

GyrA-GyrB gene mutation is responsible for 75-95% resistance to fluoroquinolones

Rrs gene is responsible for resistance to aminoglycosides 80%

questions.text: The 2nd line anti-TB drug in the following is?
questions.solution:
The first line anti tubercular drugs are: INH,rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, streptomycin.

The second line agents are the drugs that are having a low effectiveness and tolerability and hence are used only for the treatment of resistant tuberculosis. The WHO has categorized them into 3 groups.

Group A: Fluoroquinolones(Moxifloxacin and levofloxacin). Linezolid, Bedaquiline

Group B: Clofazimine and cycloserine

Group C: Delamanid, Imipenem-cilastatin/meropenem, amikacin/streptomycin, prothionamide and PAS. The first line agents Ethambutol and pyrazinamide are also included in group c.

High dose INH is also used for the treatment of MDR TB

questions.text: Which Among the following persists after Dialysis?
questions.solution:
Indications for starting RRT(Renal replacement therapy)in patients with renal impairment are-

Anorexia and nausea not attributable to other causes

Malnutrition

Electrolyte imbalance

Fluid overload

Encephalopathy and pericarditis.

Hence these symptoms will improve after dialysis.

Dialysis has no effect on peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient visited the ER for chest pain and his BP was measured as SBP 190 mmHg, DBP 70 mmHg, Pulse pressure 90 mmHg. Which of the following parameters should decrease for the high pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure = Systolic BP-Diastolic BP

The diastolic BP is determined by the arterial compliance.

The diastolic BP falls as the arterial compliance decreases as in old age.

The systolic BP is dependent on the stroke volume.

So for pulse pressure to increase, either the stroke volume has to increase or the arterial compliance has to decrease.

questions.text: In a patient with NSTEMI, which of the following would not be given?
questions.solution:
The drugs that are used in the treatment of NSTEMI are anti ischemic therapy, oral or parenteral antiplatelets and anticoagulants.

Streptokinase is a thrombolytic agent used for STEMI.

questions.text: Guillain Barre Syndrome treatment consists of all except?
questions.solution:
Steroids have no role in the treatment of GBS.

Plasma exchange and I.V immunoglobulins are the mainstay treatment whereas ventilatory support may be needed during the course of GBS.

questions.text: Which of the following will be incorrect in Rh incompatibility?
questions.solution:
In rh incompatibility, there will be hemolysis and the picture will be similar to any other hemolytic anemia. In hemolytic jaundice, in the blood we will get indirect bilirubinemia.

  • Liver function tests will be normal.
  • Since unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin, it will not be excreted in urine and hence urine will be colorless.
  • Whatever bilirubin is formed will be conjugated by the liver and excreted through the bile, where in the gut it will be converted into stercobilin and subsequently to urobilin.
  • A part of the urobilin will enter the systemic circulation where it will be excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Antidote for overdose of fibrinolytic drugs is?
questions.solution:
Fibrinolytics are drugs used to lyse a fibrin clot. Examples are Streptokinase, Urokinase, Alteplase, Tenecteplase etc.

So the drugs that are used for treating fibrinolytic overdose should be antifibrinolytics. Both tranexamic acid and EACA are anti fibrinolytics.

The antidote for fibrinolytic over dose is EACA. EACA should not be given unless the bleeding is life threatening, as EACA can cause widespread thrombosis and ischemia and can worsen DIC or HIT.

questions.text: Patient is on metoprolol and if he is given Verapamil, what is the effect that occurs ?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol is a beta blocker. It causes bradycardia by acting on the β 1 receptor in the heart.

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker and is an AV nodal blocking agent. It causes bradycardia by blocking the AV node.

In the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes, where depolarization is due primarily to a Ca2+-dependent slow inward current, the Verapamil slow the sinus pacemaker and inhibit atrioventricular conduction.

So the combined effect will be bradycardia with AV blocks.
